title: Aromatherapy & Essential Oils for Stress Relief
author: Camille Noe Pagán
description: Learn how using essential oils during aromatherapy may help improve health issues like anxiety, stress, and sleep trouble.
cleaned_text: If you need improvement in health problems from [anxiety](https://www.webmd.com/anxiety-panic/default.htm) to poor [sleep](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/default.htm), you may want to consider [aromatherapy](https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/tc/aromatherapy-essential-oils-therapy-topic-overview). In this kind of treatment, you use extracts from plants called essential oils, by either [breathing](https://www.webmd.com/lung/how-we-breathe) them through your nose or putting them on your [skin](https://www.webmd.com/beauty/cosmetic-procedures-overview-skin). Some people put the oils on their skin when they get a [massage](https://www.webmd.com/balance/massage-therapy-styles-and-health-benefits) or take a bath. What Are Essential Oils? [Essential oils](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-essential-oils) are made from flower, herb, and tree parts, like bark, roots, peels, and petals. The cells that give a plant its fragrant smell are its "essence." When an essence is extracted from a plant, it becomes an essential oil. It takes a lot of plant product to make essential oils. More than 200 pounds of lavender flowers are used to make just 1 pound of lavender essential oil. Not all products made with plant essence are essential oils. True essential oils aren't blended with other chemicals or fragrances. They're made using a specific process that doesn't change the chemistry of the plant. Lemon, chamomile, lavender, cedarwood, and bergamot are a few of the essential oils used regularly in [aromatherapy](https://www.webmd.com/balance/video/aromatherapy-benefits). How Aromatherapy Works Experts think aromatherapy activates areas in your nose called smell receptors, which send messages through your nervous system to your [brain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/picture-of-the-brain-vue3). The oils may activate certain areas of your [brain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/ss/slideshow-concussions-brain-injuries), like your limbic system, which plays a role in your emotions. They could also have an impact on your hypothalamus, which may respond to the oil by creating feel-good [brain](https://www.webmd.com/brain/rm-quiz-amazing-brain) chemicals like serotonin. Some experts think that when you put essential oils on your skin, they cause a response in your skin and other parts of your body, like your joints. What Is Aromatherapy Used For? You shouldn't use aromatherapy instead of your regular medical treatment. But for some conditions, research shows that aromatherapy can have health benefits. It may: - Ease [stress](https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/default.htm), [anxiety](https://www.webmd.com/balance/stress-management/rm-quiz-stress-anxiety), and [depression](https://www.webmd.com/depression/default.htm) - Boost feelings of relaxation - Improve [sleep](https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/ss/slideshow-sleep-disorders-overview) - Help improve quality of life for people with long-term health problems like [dementia](https://www.webmd.com/alzheimers/types-dementia) - Ease certain [types of pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/pain-types-and-classifications), including [pain](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/default.htm)from [kidney stones](https://www.webmd.com/kidney-stones/default.htm)and [osteoarthritis](https://www.webmd.com/osteoarthritis/default.htm)of the [knee](https://www.webmd.com/pain-management/knee-pain/knee-pain-overview) - Fight bacteria when you put them on your skin - Ease some of the side effects of [cancer treatment](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/understanding-cancer-treatment), like [nausea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting)and pain Is It Safe? Aromatherapy is generally safe. Essential oils can cause side effects, though. Some can irritate your [eyes](https://www.webmd.com/eye-health/picture-of-the-eyes), skin, or [mucous membranes](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/tc/sinusitis-and-mucous-membrane-topic-overview) in your nose. They can also cause mild allergic reactions. If you drink some essential oils they can hurt your [kidneys](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-kidney-disease-basic-information) or [liver](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-liver-failure). It's rare that people take essential oils by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/anatomy-of-the-mouth), and you shouldn't do it unless your doctor says it's OK. If you're new to aromatherapy, work with an aromatherapist or your doctor. And keep in mind that essential oils aren't regulated by the FDA, which means that unlike [drugs](https://www.webmd.com/drugs/index-drugs.aspx), the agency doesn't check to see if they're safe or work the way they're supposed to.
